title: Suite enterprise readiness
content:
This page provides a brief overview of the enterprise readiness of the suite.

Deployment mode

You can deploy the suite on-premises, in the cloud, or on OpenShift. 

High availability (HA)

The suite can achieve high availability through failure recovery, failover, and load balancing.

Failure recovery

Failure recovery follows the restart policy of Kubernetes. The policy is specified as Always, all pods should be restarted automatically after a failure occurs. As designed in Kubernetes, failed containers are restarted by kubelet with an exponential back-off delay (10s, 20s, 40s, and so on) capped at five minutes, and are reset after ten minutes of successful execution.

Failover

The suite will fail over a resource to protect against a failed service. For example, when the pod hosting the resource becomes inactive, or the resources within the pod fail. During a failover process, the service will switch from the failed pod/resource to another redundant one.

A pod is the smallest deployable object in the Kubernetes object model and it represents a running process on your cluster. Pods are a model of the pattern of multiple cooperating processes that form a cohesive unit of service. For more information about each service and its description, see Service dependency. You can also find a pod failure recovery time report in the Appendix section of this document.

OMT utilizes the HA feature of Keepalived to support control plane node failover. The Keepalived daemon on the active control plane node periodically sends the Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol (VRRP) advertisements to other control plane nodes in the cluster. To learn more about OMT HA, see Configure High Availability in a cluster with multiple control plane nodes.

Load balancing

In a typical enterprise application architecture, a load balancer in front of application servers increases security, scalability, and flexibility. SMA uses Nginx as a bundled load balancer to distribute incoming traffic to internal application servers and can work on a single instance or multiple control plane nodes.

In addition to the bundled load balancer, SMA is also compatible with the external load balancer. As the SMA frontend Ingress works in the active-standby mode, the external load balancer can only serve as a reverse proxy, forwarding incoming traffic to active SMA frontend Ingress. Serving as a reverse proxy, the external load balancer can be configured to work on both layer 4 (TCP) and layer 7 (HTTPS). 

Be sure of the following if you deploy the external load balancer before installing the SMA suite: 

  1. Set the FQDN of SMA to that of the load balancer during the OMT installation.
  2. Set the target server of the external load balancer to the control plane node, or the virtual IP address of control plane nodes if deployed with multiple control plane nodes. 

Be sure of the following if you deploy the external load balancer after installing the SMA suite:

  1. Set the target server of the external load balancer to SMA's control plane node, or the virtual IP address of control plane nodes if deployed with multiple control plane nodes.
  2. Replace the FQDN of SMA with that of the load balancer.

Scalability

When the suite is deployed on-premises or in the cloud, you can perform manual scaling on certain pods listed in the table in the Appendix section. 

Backup and restore

You can back up and restore Kubernetes configurations by using the open-source tool Velero.

For the PostgreSQL database and external storage data, you can use cloud native backup/restore services.

For more information, see Back up and restore.

Update

You can upgrade the suite to newer versions or apply patches to it. 

For more information, see Upgrade. 

Sizing

You can specify the suite sizing during installation based on your use case. For more information, see the following topics:

  • Sizing for on-premises deployment 
  • Sizing considerations for AKS deployment
  • Sizing considerations for EKS deployment
  • Sizing considerations for OpenShift deployment

You can also increase your deployment size before a suite version upgrade. The new size takes effect only when the version update is completed.

Security

You can import users from LDAP or federated SAML IdP to the suite. For more information, see How to edit an account.

Observability

You can configure a proper monitoring mechanism so that you are aware of any potential issues with your worker nodes, pods, and services. For more information, see Observe SMA.

Openl10n support

By using the Openl10n community site, you can localize the system (Service Portal and the agent portal) into additional languages that aren't officially supported. For more information, see Localize the system by using Openl10n.

Appendix

This section provides the following information:

  • A table that outlines the detailed supportability for certain capabilities
  • A pod failure recovery time report that lists the Mean Time to Repair (MTTR) for the pods. The time is calculated based on a specific system configuration (1 control plane node + 2 worker nodes with 8 CPU/32G Memory, 50 self-service users, and 50 IT agent users) in a lab environment. The actual time may vary depending on your suite size.
